intro: Pinaropappus pooleanus, commonly known as the Poole's pappus plant, is a rare flowering species native to specific regions of southern Europe. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of numerous small florets. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and thrives in sunny, well-drained environments. Its unique morphology includes a hairy stem and small, daisy-like flowers that bloom in late summer. Due to habitat loss, it is considered endangered and is protected in several conservation programs.
